Pinkey is 37 years old and is a divorced lady living with her mother, sister and her brother-in-law. Pinkey is an active woman having good rapport with her neighbors. She does not want to be a burden on her sister's family. She started a general store in her village with the support of her sister and her brother-in-law, who is a daily laborer. She sells biscuits, cakes, wafers, chocolates, etc. and she wants to add some variety items like pens, notebooks, pencils, rice, lentils, etc. There is no other general store in her village and the demand for the items is great but she is not able to get the products due to her poor financial condition. 

She applied for a loan of 36,000 INR to purchase the above products for her general store. She says that if she adds a variety of items then she can meet the customers' demand and increase her income.

loans.use: to purchase pens, notebooks, pencils, rice, lentils, etc. for her general store

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah is 34 years old mother of three children, actually Aida as all mothers she wants to provide a high quality life for her ‎children and she working hard to do that, therefore she wants to use her free time in something useful, so she decided to ‎be a productive woman and help her husband in the expenses of her children.‎
She started to sell blankets and bed`s covers, when she felt that she is working well and she gets good incomes from this ‎work, she decided to expand her work, therefore she applied for a loan to help develop her work and buy more kinds of ‎blankets and bed`s cover and to add covers for tables to sell and increase her incomes.‎

loans.use: to help him make a good promotion for his ‎business to attract more customers so increase his incomes

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Ms. Marie D. is a divorced woman who takes care of three children. As she is quite gifted in the identification and analysis of business opportunities, she has chosen to get into the business of selling fish and condiments, in which she is doing rather well. However, due to her very limited financial means, she is confronted with high demand that she is unable to meet. She currently needs a loan, which will allow her to increase the size of her business in order to increase her revenue. She is requesting a loan of $700, which will give her the capital to buy and resell fish and condiments. This new possibility will allow her to meet not only the needs of her customers but also those of her family. This will allow Ms. D. to live off the fruits of her labor and to better meet her immediate needs, notably the feeding, clothing, health and education of her children.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame D. Marie est une femme divorcée avec trois (3) enfants à charge. Très douée dans l’identification et dans l’analyse des opportunités d’affaires, elle s’est choisie pour activité principale la vente de poissons et condiments qui lui réussit assez bien. Cependant, par ses moyens financiers très limités, elle est confrontée à beaucoup de demandes qu’elle est incapable de satisfaire. Elle a besoin aujourd’hui d’un appui financier qui lui servira à augmenter la taille de son activité en vue d’accroître son chiffre d’affaires. Elle sollicite un crédit de $700 qui lui permettra de disposer d’un fonds de commerce pour l’achat et la revente du poisson et des condiments. Cette nouvelle possibilité lui permettra de satisfaire non seulement les besoins de sa clientèle mais aussi ceux de sa famille. Ceci permettra à Madame D. de vivre du fruit de son travail et de mieux subvenir à ses besoins immédiats, notamment: l’alimentation, la santé, l’habillement et l’éducation de ses enfants.

loans.use: To buy and sell fish and condiments

loans.name: Juana Inés

texts.en:
Juana Inés is 48 years old. She is an enthusiastic, hardworking and responsible woman. She used to work as an employee in a business but she lost her job, and had to find a way to support her mother, who at her advanced age needs medical attention and medicines. That was when she decided to start her own business, selling groceries. This business allows her not only to earn the resources she needs to support the family, but also to spend more time with her mother. In 1995 she started her business in a vacant lot she reconditioned to serve as her store. Little by little she has continued to grow her business and with the help of an aunt she has been able to move it ahead.

Now Juana needs a loan of $750 to buy merchandise and make improvements to her store. She agrees to repay the loan in 5 to 10 months. She has confidence in people who help those who need it most, and she appreciates your help.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Juana Inés tiene 48 años de edad, es una mujer entusiasta, trabajadora y responsable, ella trabajaba como empleada en una empresa pero quedó desempleada y tenía a su cargo a su madre que es de edad avanzada y necesita de atención médica y medicinas. Entonces decidió iniciar su propio negocio y vender productos de abarrotes, este negocio le permitió, además de obtener los recursos necesarios para el sustento, pasar más tiempo al cuidado de su madre. En 1995 inició su negocio en un terreno baldío que fue acondicionando para poner su tienda. Poco a poco ha ido surtiendo su negocio y con ayuda de su tía han podido salir adelante.

Ahora Juana necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 750 dólares que utilizará para impulsar su negocio con la compra de mercancía y mejorar el aspecto de su local, mismo que esta dispuesta a devolver en un plazo de 5 a 10 meses. Ella confía en las personas que ayudan a quien más lo necesita y agradece tu apoyo.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Ana Isabel

texts.en:
My name is Ana B. and I make a living selling new clothes. I've had my business for the past three years. Because I am located near the bus station, in one of the busiest streets of my city, I have a lot of good customers. My goal is to increase my product stock and thus increase my sales. With my earnings I will feed my family and buy wood to fix my shop.

Translated by Kiva volunteer Maite Barragán

Mi nombre es Ana B. me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva, tengo mi negocio hace 3 años, estoy ubicada cerca de una estacion de buses en un lugar muy transitado de mi ciudad por lo tanto tengo muchos clientes muy buenos, mi meta es incrementar mi inventario y mis ventas y con las ganancias que obtenga poder alimentar mi familia y comprar madera para arreglar mi negocio.

loans.use: purchasing new clothes for ladies, men and children

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Mrs. Miriam A. lives in a home she owns in the Llojeta Bajo neighborhood of La Paz. She is a widow and has four children, but only one child who is still a dependent.

She works mornings at a bakery owned by one of her sons; in the afternoons, she works as a hair stylist in her own beauty salon. On Saturday afternoons she teaches hairstyling at a beauty school in the city of El Alto.

This loan is to be used to finance her son's thesis coursework at Salesiana University. This is the first time she has requested a loan through IMPRO, and IMPRO's financial analysis indicates that she has sufficient income to repay this loan and cover her and her dependent child's living expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

La Señora Miriam A. vive en casa propia ubicada en la zona de Llojeta Bajo en la calle Valle Vergelito Nº 1146 de la ciudad de La Paz. La señora es viuda tiene cuatro hijos, pero bajo su dependencia se encuentra solo uno.

Trabaja en la mañana en la pastelería de su hijo y luego en la tarde se va al salón de belleza de su propiedad, ubicado en la calle Jaimes Freyre de la ciudad de La Paz, donde se dedica a los peinados (ella es peinadora), y los días sábados en la tarde dicta clases de peluquería en un instituto de belleza de la ciudad de el Alto.

El destino del crédito es para colaborar a uno de sus hijos en la elaboración de su tesis de la Universidad Salesiana. No tiene crédito con Impro, pues es la primera vez que acude a nuestra Institución. El análisis financiero indica que cuenta con suficientes ingresos como para pagar el crédito solicitado y cubrir sus necesidades particulares y las de su hijo que aun depende de ella.

loans.use: To finance her son's thesis coursework at the university

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy laundry products such as detergent and bleach.

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
We found Maruja very happily and eagerly cleaning her restaurant, which is the only source of income her and her husband, Cristóbal, count on to provide for their family. In this small but cosy restaurant they prepare the richest stews at the best prices in the area, thanks to their good seasoning and customer service. Maruja is pleased with the results, but her goal is to enlarge and refurbish her small rented site with the hope of providing more comfort and personal attention to their customers. With the increased income, they could also improve their own home and offer more comfort to their 9-year-old child. To carry out their plans in a short amount of time, they are requesting a loan and thank you for your generous heart and selfless support.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Encontramos a doña Maruja, muy alegre y afanosa haciendo la limpieza de su restaurante, único ingreso económico con el que cuentan junto a su esposo, Cristóbal, para mantener a su familia; en este pequeño pero acogedor restaurante preparan los potajes más ricos y económicos de su zona, negocio que gracias a su buena sazón y trato que ofrece a sus clientes obtiene día a día asiduos comensales. Ella se siente contenta con los resultados que está obteniendo pero el deseo que tiene en mente es ampliar y refaccionar su pequeño local alquilado, con el fin de brindarles una mejor comodidad y atención a las personas que visitan día a día su pequeño espacio de ventas, así mismo con los beneficios que obtenga ofrecerle una morada cómoda y propia a su pequeño retoño de nueve años de edad.Para concretar sus planes solicita un préstamo con el que gracias a tu generoso corazón y apoyo desinteresado podrá concretar en muy corto tiempo sus planes.

loans.use: Renovate and enlarge a small restaurant.

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Sreymom, 29, and her husband, Mao Sophal, have been married for 2 years. They have one 13-month-old daughter. Until recently, they lived with Sreymom's older brother and his family where they learned how to grow flowers. Now, they have a small, thatched home of their own and a neighbor has given them permission to farm his fallow land. Sophal also works as a construction mason, a skill he learned when only a teenager.

Sreymom is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $500. She will use this loan to purchase flower transplants from neighbors to add to the few from her brother. In total, they plan to grow four different varieties of flowers. A portion of the loan will also be used to purchase fertilizer. From the time of planting, it will be 2-3 months before Sreymom can begin picking the flowers. Some, she will bring to Phnom Penh to sell direct; others will be sold to a local buyer that visits the area. As the rotation of flowers will grow year-round; this will provide them with a steady income and financial independence.

loans.use: Buy flower transplants and fertilizer

loans.name: Kireku E Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for six months. Florence has a clothes selling business. With the extra business profits, Florence intends to buy a piece of land. Fatumah and Mastula sell charcoal. Rose runs a canteen while Safina offers catering services.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase stock and expand their businesses.

loans.name: Dionisio

texts.en:
Dionisio R. is a 56-year-old married father of six children. His children are all grown and live and work on their own. In order to bring in sufficient income, he is the owner of two public buses that have routes throughout the surrounding cities. The company that he works for is Tapiracuay.

Dionisio has many dedicated clientele who use his buses. However Dionisio is still looking to expand his business and he hopes to have saved enough to soon buy another bus. The loan he is asking for will be used to fix the two buses he owns to give his clientele a more comfortable ride.

loans.use: To fix two buses

loans.name: Maritza

texts.en:
Maritza C. D. Aguilla runs a small shop where she sells candy in the district of Yarina Cocha, department Ucayali.  She also sells sodas, fruit, ice cream and juices.  Maritza has many loyal clients, most of whom are neighborhood children.  To promote her business and continue to grow, Maritza conducts raffles and lotteries and serves homemade chocolate milk to all her clients during Christmas.
	
Maritza is 34 years old, single, and has no children.  She is very driven and has big plans for her future.  She currently studies nursing at a local university.  She is also excited to expand her business and start selling medicinal plants. 
	
A member of the community bank Las Azucenas, Maritza is requesting a loan of s/1200 to repay over 4 months.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for a sweets shop

loans.name: Maura's Group

texts.en:
Maura is the coordinator of a group of five women, all of whom are entrepreneurs which operate their own businesses in the Los R. community of San Cristobal. Maura is fifty-eight years old and a proud mother of seven grownup sons, each one living with his respective family. Maura explains that her husband passed away eight years ago and she was left alone to face all the responsibilities. She spent almost all her savings to start a small cafeteria. She explains that in the beginning, it was really difficult to run the cafeteria. She remembers that she had to face an arduous competition, and the access to capital was complicated.

Now, Maura’s cafeteria is relatively stable and she has a lot of customers that visit her everyday to enjoy her appetizing plates. Maura would like to leave the local stall (made of wood) within which she’s operating her cafeteria and build a concrete one in a few years. With her loan, Maura will buy raw materials and other goods to prepare her food and keep satisfying her clients.

The members of Maura’s group are: Santa Patricia S. C., a grocery store’s owner; Yenny Gabriela R. A., to invest in her store; Anicia S. C. will buy more goods for her clothing store; Fiordaliza S. G., to purchase women’s clothing to resell in her community.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials and many other goods for a small cafeteria.

loans.name: Taulaai

texts.en:
Taulaai F., 41, is married with 6 children. She has 4 years of experience selling taro and bananas to the general public in the main market 5 days per week. She will use the loan for her farm and will also purchase her children's sportswear for school. Her husband is her right hand in her business, supporting her and their children.

Taulaai has had a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to now be 250 Tala (about $US104). SPBD loans are Taulaai’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase more taro tops, a crowbar, wheelbarrow and pesticides

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma is a 33-year-old woman from the village of Banovići, which is near the town of the same name.  She is married with 2 children, and her husband works in a coal mine in the town of Banovići.  To help support her family, Alma works in agriculture and breeds cattle.  She earns her income primarily from selling milk and milk products.  This is her second loan with WWI. She has asked for 1200 KM to buy chickens to fatten, after which she can sell them for a profit.   Her wish is to help support her family by growing her business.

loans.use: To buy chickens to raise and sell.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca K. produces ‘tie and dye’ fabric for sale. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Rebecca and her 1 child. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Rebecca is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Julia Edilberta

texts.es:
Julia is 50 and lives with her husband Pedro and their six children, who are all adults now and working. Together, the family is trying to improve its standard of living. Julia owns two motorcycle trishaws that her sons maintain and operate to transport passengers. Furthermore, Julia sells clothes in various locations in her region from 6:00 in the morning to 6:00 in the evening. She has been conducting this activity for the past three years. She likes her work because she feels it is useful to society. With her loan, she wants to buy spare parts to maintain and repair one of her motorcycles, buy more garments to sell and then rent a location to set up her clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Ian Harvey, Kiva volunteer.

Julia, de 50 años vive a lado de su esposo Pedro y sus 6 hijos que ya son adultos y trabajan. Esta familia, en unión, busca mejorar su calidad de vida. Julia es propietaria de dos motocarros, son sus hijos los que las cuidan y manejan haciendo trasporte de pasajeros. Adicionalmente, Julia se dedica a la venta de ropa por los distintos lugares de su zona, desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde. Ella lleva en esta actividad desde hace 3 años. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo, es que le hace sentir útil a la sociedad. Con el dinero que solicita en préstamo, quiere comprar repuestos para el mantenimiento y arreglo de una de sus motos, comprar más prendas para su venta, y posteriormente alquilar un local para poner su tienda de ropa.

loans.use: Motorcycle repairs and purchase of wholesale merchandise (clothing)

loans.name: Milenium Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal las “MILENIUM”, se fundo el 12 de Noviembre de 1998, actualmente se encuentra en el II ciclo 16 mujeres y 6 varones, es un banco comunal conformado por socias que viven en el distrito Calca en la calle Bolivar Nº 128 a 50 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco, las actividades económicas a las que se dedican son el comercio de productos agrícolas  y servicios venta de comidas dentro del mercado y artesanía. El banco comunal tiene 10 años de funcionamiento, como manifiestan las socias, se encuentran contentas y satisfechas con los servicios de crédito, ahorro y capacitación, por el tiempo de permanencia en el banco comunal un aspecto de valoración es el ahorro por la posibilidad de capitalización que les brinda este servicio.
“El ahorro lo utilizo para que mi hija estudie en Cusco” “He mejoR. mi casa con el ahorro”,  "Mi hija puede estudiar ahora con luz electrica" son algunas expresiones de las socias que nos alienta a seguir trabajando bancos comunales. Calca esta ubicado en el Valle SagR. de los Incas, en la cuenca del rió Vilcanota, cuenta con un clima templado. Los días de feria local son los domingos, es cuando las socias realizan sus actividades comerciales.
texts.en:
The community bank "MILENIUM", was founded on November 12, 1998. Its members consist of 16 women and 6 men, who live in the Calca district on Bolivar Street No. 128. It is located 50 minutes from the city of Cusco, Peru. The economic activities of those engaged with this bank are trade in agricultural products and services involving the sale of food and crafts at markets. The community bank has been in operation for 10 years, and its members are happy and satisfied with its services of loans, savings and training it offers. The following are some quotes from members who encourage the use of community bank services: "I use the savings for my daughter to study in Cusco", "I've improved my house with the savings," "My daughter can now study using light from electricity." The Calca district is located in the Valle SagR. de los Incas (the sacred valley of the Incas), in the Vilcanota River basin, which has a temperate climate. The local fair days fall on Sundays, and this is when the members conduct their business activities.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The members of this community bank typically use their loans in order to purchase more merchandise to grow their business. ( Las socias del banco comunal, destinan sus creditos para actividades de comercio, principalmente es capital de trabajo, para incrementar el stock de mercaderia, acopiar productos.)

loans.name: Mayernith

texts.es: Mayernith tiene 38 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos estudiantes, su esposo Sixto, quien es trabajador independiente la apoya mucho, y ambos desean salir adelante y brindar a sus hijos lo necesario. Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes desde hace varios años atrás y por su amabilidad y buena atención cuenta con gran cantidad de clientes, que siempre le mencionan y sugieren las cosas que faltan en su bodega, y ella trata de satisfacerlos, porque como ella nos dice “el cliente tiene la razón”. Adicionalmente se dedica a la venta de comida, solo lo hace para la hora del almuerzo. Mayernith quiere implementar su negocio, así como también modificar algunas partes de su vivienda, es por eso que requiere de un préstamo para realizar estos objetivos.
texts.en:
Mayernith is 38 years old and a mother of 3 school aged children. Her husband Sixto is an independent worker, supports her a lot and both desire to get ahead and provide their children with everything they need. She has worked selling groceries for several years and thanks to her friendliness and customer service she has a large number of customers that always suggest the products that her store lack. She tries to satisfy these request because, as she says, the customer is always right. She also works selling food, which she does at lunchtime. Mayernith wants to expand her business, as well as improve various parts of her house, and for this reason she needs a loan to fulfill these objectives.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand the merchandise in her store

loans.name: Sy-Koutiala-00050 Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Benkadi de l’association Sodia ont en moyenne 40 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de N’tonaso de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative du Mali)
Liées par des relations essentiellement de parenté, elles mènent différentes activités qui va de la fabrication du savon, de la teinture, la restauration à la vente des produits cosmétiques.
 C’est dans leurs recherches de ressources complémentaires qu’elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis cinq années. Après neuf prêts solidaires tous remboursés sans difficulté, les membres de ce groupe sont à leurs dixièmes prêts. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, cents kilogrammes d’ haricots, 20 litres d’huiles alimentaires et d’autres ingrédients (colorants, potasses etc.).au grand marché de Koutiala auprès des commerçants des domaines concernés.
Les articles vendus au marché, à la maison, dans les gargotes et de façon ambulante à une clientèle riche et variée. 
Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 100 000FCFA. de bénéfice par cycle qui sera utilisé pour développer leurs activités.
texts.en:
The four women of the Benkadi group of Sodia association have an average age of 40 and, on average, 4 children. They live in big extended traditional families in the village of N’tonaso in the prefecture of Koutiala (3rd administrative region of Mali).

United essentially by bonds of family, they have various businesses: from making soap to doing dyeing, to food service and selling cosmetics. It was in their search for additional financial resources that they decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso 5 years ago. After 9 solidarity loans, all reimbursed without difficulty, the members of this group are on their 10th loan.

This loan will be used to buy 100 kg of beans, 20 liters of cooking oil, and other business items (dyes, potash, etc.) in the big market of Koutiala, from merchants who sell those goods.

Their merchandise is sold in the market, out of their homes, or door-to-door to a richly varied clientele. They are counting on making an average profit of 100,000 F CFA per loan cycle which will be used to expand their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items (cosmetics, food ingredients, raw materials for soap-making and dyeing)

loans.name: Benjamín Felix

texts.es: El Sr. Benjamin, es un hombre muy trabajador, que desde pequeño, demostró sus cualidades manuales, es así que aprendiendo de su madre aprende los oficios de la costura y el bordado, trabaja junto a su esposa quien le ayuda en la elaboración de ropa interior femenina en un pequeño taller ubicado en su casa, labor que realiza desde hace varios años de forma artesanal, y gracias a su trabajo mantiene a sus dos hijos, quienes tambien han demostrado habilidad para la costura y confección artesanal de ropa interior femenina, es así que toda la familia se dedica a la costura. Toda la familia trabaja muy duro con el sueño de hacer ampliar su pequeña casa para así tener un taller más amplio y vivir más comodamente.
texts.en:
Benjamin is a hard working man. Since a young age, he has demonstrated a talent for manual skills and was able to learn sewing and embroidering from his mother. He works with his wife, whom he helps making women’s interior garments in a small workshop in their house. He has been doing this work for many years and is thus able to support his two children, whom also have a talent for making women’s interior garments. Therefore, the entire family is dedicated to sewing. The family works very hard with the hope of expanding their small house to have a larger workshop and to live more comfortably.

Translated from Spanish by Lucia Franzese, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials

loans.name: Flor Magaly

texts.es:
Flor Sánchez C. forma parte del Banco Comunal “Niño Manuelito II” de la provincia de Huaraz.

Flor tiene 23 años y es madre soltera de una niña, la dificultad mas grande para ella ha sido tener que enfrentar la separación de su conviviente hace tres años ella afirma “ser padre y madre para mi hija” es un reto muy grande, ella en la actualidad no tiene un negocio estable debido a que cuando su hija ingresó al jardín le ha dificultado realizar la actividad que siempre ha realizado el de vender comida y brindar alimentación a los trabajadores de la zona de Tacllán que trabajan en la extracción de arena y agregados de construcción, ella espera mejorar y reintegrarse al trabajo pronto porque su hija saldrá de vacaciones.
  
Con este préstamo de s/.1700.00, que pagará en seis cuotas lo destinará en el arreglo de su casa para el enlucido con yeso de las paredes y techo de su casa y tener mejores condiciones de vida debido a que actualmente es totalmente de adobes y tierra.
 
A flor le gustaría aprender otras alternativas de negocio y continuar trabajando.
texts.en:
Flor Sánchez C. is part of the communal bank “Niño Manuelito II” in the province of Huaraz.

Flor is 23 years old and is the single mother of one little girl. Her greatest difficulty has been dealing with the separation from her partner three years ago. She states that "being the father and mother for my daughter" is a difficult challenge. She does not currently have a stable business since, when her daughter entered kindergarten, it became difficult for her to carry out her former job of selling food and bringing it to the workers in the Tacllán region who extract sand and other construction aggregates. She hopes it will get better and she can get back into her work soon because her daughter will be out for vacations.

With this loan for $575, which she will repay in six payments, she will make repairs to her home to replaster the walls and roof of her home and improve their living conditions, since the house is currently made of adobe and earth.

Flor would like to learn other ways of doing business and to continue working.


Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repairs on the front, walls, and roof of her house.

loans.name: Adzo

texts.fr: Adzo A. est âgée de 43 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle est revendeuse de bassines et ustensiles de cuisines au grand marché de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. elle espère avec ce crédit accroître la capacité de son commerce en approvisionnant sa boutique afin de mieux répondre aux besoins de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Adzo A. is 43 years old, married and the mother of four children. She is a reseller of plastic bowls and kitchen utensils at the large Lomé market, in Togo's capital. With this loan, she hopes to increase her business's capacity by stocking up her shop in order to better meet her customers' demand.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of plastic bowl and kitchen utensils for resale

loans.name: Aurelio

texts.en:
Mr. Aurelio M. is 50 years old and he is married with two children. He is the owner of a small store, Despensa San Antonio, and he has cows that produce milk that he also sells in his store. Mr. M. also makes and sells cheese.

Mr. M. has run the store for more than 25 years; sales are usually good because the store is located in the downtown area of the city of Piribebuy, where one can find a good crowd of people every day of the week.

Thanks to the loan he will receive from Fundación Paraguaya, Mr. Megarejo will keep his store well-stocked and he will be able to buy more merchandise of all sorts, especially products that are sold on a daily basis: meat, sugar, oil, eggs, noodles, etc.

Mr. M. states that he needs to buy a three-door freezer to keep drinks cold because on the weekends his drink sales are very strong. In the hot summer months, cold drinks are the products that sell most, along with chicken and beef.

loans.use: purchase of goods such as meat, milk, eggs, sugar, flour, sodas, beer, rice, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr: M. kossi est un homme marié qui habite le quartier d’agbalépédogan, il a 03 enfants et sa femme est une revendeuse. Il a ouvert une boutique qu’il a appelé Ets M. Kossi dans laquelle il fait le commerce de pièces détachées. Il fait ce commerce depuis 2002 et c’est avec cette activité qu’il arrive à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Actuellement  il ne dispose pas de certaines pièces que ses clients demandent, il demande alors un crédit pour pouvoir acheter des pièces détachées.
texts.en:
M. Kossi is a married man who lives in the Agbalépédogan neighborhood. He has three children, and his wife is a reseller. In 2002, he opened a store called "Ets M. Kossi" where he sells spare parts. Since then, he has been running this business, which enables him to provide for his family. At this time, he's lacking some spare parts that his clients are looking for. He's therefore seeking a loan in order to be able to purchase these spare parts.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell spare parts

loans.name: La Inca Group

texts.es:
El grupo solidario Inca está conformado por tres señoras, todas ellas son mujeres trabajadoras, originarias de la comarca del mismo nombre del grupo, ubicada en el departamento de Masaya, sus condiciones de vida son humildes, trabajan con Adim porque les gusta que confíen en ellas, expresaron..
Son vecinas, de confianza, se conocen hace muchos años y son muy unidas. Doña Darling vende productos lácteos, doña Susana M. vende ropa ambulante y Doña Darling G. vende ropa y cosméticos ambulante.

Doña Darling E. G. es una joven de 28 años, casada, madre de tres hijos de las edades  5, 3 y un bebé de 2 meses. Doña Darling se dedica a la compra y venta de productos lácteos como : crema, queso, cuajadas, leche, etc., los cuales las va ha vender en el mercado de Masaya. Ella sueña con comprar un terreno para construir su casita, puesto que actualmente vive con su suegra, hacer que crezca su negocio, y darle una buena educación a sus hijos.

Este grupo está comprometido a pagar puntual y así seguir obteniendo créditos con Adim, están seguras que con el crédito saldrán adelante porque incrementan sus ventas y así sus ingresos.
texts.en:
The group Inca is made up of three women, all hard working women from the area of the same name as the group, located in the Masaya region. Their living conditions are humble. They all say they work with Adim because they trust the organization. These women are neighbors who trust each other. They have known each other for many years and are very close. Mrs. Darling E. sells dairy products, Mrs. Susana M. sells clothing in the streets and Mrs. Darling G. sells clothing and cosmetics, also in the streets. Mrs. Darling E. G. is 28 years old, married and the mother of 3 children, ages, 5, 3 and a 2 month old baby. Darling works buying and sellling dairy products such as cream, cheese, cuajada (a dessert made of curdled milk), milk, etc. She goes to the Masaya market to sell her products. She dreams of buying a plot of land where she can build a house. She currently lives with her mother in law. She also dreams of growing her business and giving her children a good education. This group is committed to pay punctually in order to continue receiving loans from Adim, They are confident that with this loan they wil move ahead by increasing their sales and as a result, their earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria G. is 45 years old. She is married and has five kids. All the kids are currently in school. She lives with her family in their own house at Oda, a farming community in the eastern Ghana. Victoria works hard to support her kids’ welfare and schooling. She sells foodstuffs and vegetables. She sells maize, beans, yams, tomatoes, onions, eggplant, etc., at a stand in the community market. She buys her goods from the farmers in the surrounding villages. She has been in business for five years. She also distributes the maize and beans to local food vendors. She wants a loan to buy foodstuffs in bulk so that she can make fewer trips to procure the goods and in this way maximize profit.

She is a member of the community group called “Yehowa Mma” (Jehovah's children). Members of this group guarantee each other's loans and support one another in handling repayment of the loans.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs in bulk.

loans.name: Bosede

texts.en:
Bosede is 60 years old. She is a widow with eight children. She sells foodstuffs and provisions.

She is requesting a loan amount of N50,000 so that she can purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchsae more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is 59 years old and sells generic medicines in her village. She has been a widow for about 18 years. Her husband passed when her youngest child was merely four years old. She has six children and is glad that some of them have their own good jobs that support their own families. Her youngest is now 22 years old and still lives with her. Josefina’s grandchildren inspire her every time she sees them and that keeps her working hard to expand her business.  

Josefina sells generic medicines in different villages near her place to generate a daily income to support her children's and grandchildren’s need. She is very proud that even though she is already a widow it has not been a hindrance for her to pursue working and provide financial support to her children. Josefina is requesting a loan of PHP 13,000 which will be used as her additional working capital in expanding her current business.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: growing maize and manioc

loans.name: La Fortaleza Group 2

texts.en:
Dionorat is the leader of the group L. Fortaleza 2, which translates as "The Strength." This group is seeking a loan to help them grow their small businesses in the town of Hato Mayor on the eastern sector of the Dominican Republic. This is a group maD. up of friends and family that has successfully taken out three loans in the past and has supported one another in their entrepreneurial ventures.

Diornat owns a clothing store that she started two years ago. With this loan, she will buy more pants and blouses to sell in her store. She hopes to increase her profits so that she can continue to support her two children, aged 13 and 16, and be able to send them to college.

Diornat and the entire L. Fortaleza 2 group have greatly appreciated the opportunities that their microloans have given them and they hope to continue in their success.

loans.use: To buy pants and blouses for her clothing store.

loans.name: Marly

texts.es: Marly tiene 37 años, tiene 5 hijos: 2 estudiantes y 3 que trabajan. También vive junto a su esposo quien ejerce diversos oficios, es agricultor, constructor y carpintero. La casa donde habitan es propia. Desde hace 14 años ella se dedica a la venta de plátanos y otras frutas regionales, negocio que atiende en la parte de afuera de su casa. Lo que le gusta de esta actividad es el contacto directo con las personas, a quienes les brinda un buen trato cuando se acercan a comprarle alguno de sus productos. Además, Marly considera que su negocio es rentable porque la producción de las frutas que vende es abundante y son consumidas diariamente las personas. Para más adelante quiere tener un negocio de venta de abarrotes, ya que sus clientes están empezando a pedirle que venda otros productos comestibles. Este es su 6to crédito con MFP, menciona que lo que le gusta de su banco comunal es que entre todos los integrantes se apoyan mutuamente y son responsables en sus cuotas de pago. El dinero que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de más frutas y plátanos, además mandará a construir un kiosco para vender con mayor comodidad.
texts.en:
Marly is 37, and she has five children. Two are students, and three work. She also lives with her husband who works at different trades. He is a farmer, construction worker, and a carpenter. The house they live in is their own. For 14 years she has been selling bananas and other regional fruit. She tends this business in the front of her house. She likes this work because of the direct contact with people. She treats them well when they come to buy her products. Also, Marly considers her business to be profitable because fruit production is abundant where she lives, and people eat fruit every day. Later, she wants to have a business selling groceries. Her customers are starting to ask her to sell other food products. This is her sixth loan with MFP. What she likes about her community bank is that all of the members support each other, and they are responsible about their payments. She will use the money she is asking for to buy more fruit and bananas. She will also build a kiosk to sell more comfortably.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie P. is a 38-year-old farmer and single mother with one child. She also raises chickens as a means of additional income. She owns a 6-hectare farm. She is worried because the farm has remained unplanted. She has decided to utilize the farm for growing vegetables, coconuts, and rice.

She would like to ask for a loan of 6,000 PHP to be able to get started in her plan. She will use the loan to purchase four bags of ammonium sulfate, as well as farm chemicals. She is a very optimistic woman and hopes very much for the possibility of success in her business.

Now, she is actively involved in the CEVI credit program. She receives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase four bags of ammonium sulfate, as well as farm chemicals

loans.name: His Majesty Group

texts.en:
Emelia is 40 years old, and is married with one child who is currently in school. To support her household, Emelia has been selling cereals such as maize, beans and groundnuts in her neighborhood to loyal customers. She says selling these products is very lucrative. Therefore she is requesting a loan to expand her inventory to make more income to support her family. Emelia takes delivery of stock from suppliers in the northern region of Ghana and retails to her customers. She would be grateful for your support.

Emelia (shown seated in the photograph) is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘His Majesty’. Most of the members of this group are small traders, food vendors, etc. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cereals such as groundnuts, maize and beans

loans.name: Pannha

texts.en:
Mr. Pannha A. is a plaster decorator. He was married in 2007 and lives with his wife, who is a garment factory worker, and his mother on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Pannha doesn’t have his own transportation, so he is applying for a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia D., 39 years old is a rice grower in Vereula Agusan Del Sur. She was blessed with one child and is one year old already. Her dreams for her child is to grow healthy and finish a college degree in the future.

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm by buying the farming necessities to have an abundant harvest. The loan is really helpful to grow her business more to be able to save money for future use.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda is 43 years old and lives in Cabisera 25, Ilagan, Isabela. She is married and has three children: Roland, Orly and Luzilyn. Luzviminda is striving hard to make her business more profitable in order to sustain the needs of her children. Her husband sells bamboo in different villages. 

Luzviminda has a business buying and selling personal products, such as Avon, in her village. She started her business in 2003, and she is aiming to further expand her business. In addition, Luzviminda also sells snacks and food in the village. It is of great benefit to her family because it is where their daily allowances come from. 

Luzviminda requests loan of PHP 5,000 to use as additional capital in maintaining and improving the business. This amount will be of big help to make her business more profitable. Soon, with her profits, she may also be able to contribute to the progress of her husband’s business. She hopes that through this loan, they can gradually improve their way of living.

loans.use: Capital to maintain and improve her sales business

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Mrs. Yen S. is a villager in Tonle village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Nak Saroeun, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice to earn for living. In this plantation, they earn less income than needed to support their family. In order to support her family, Mrs. Yen S. is asking for a loan to buy a motorbike for her son so he can be a motorbike taxi driver. She is 44 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is a motorbike taxi driver.  Two are attending the local school and the others are too young to work or study. Her husband is present in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her son's taxi business.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda A. is a beautician and manicurist in the village of San Jose, Santiago City. She is thankful because her business is improving. However, the income she generates is not enough considering the high cost of commodities. So, she would like to apply for a loan to use as additional capital in her business. She will utilize the loan for buying more equipment for her beauty salon. She is requesting a loan in the amount of PHP 5,000. This amount she is requesting will serve as a big help in developing her business.

Luzviminda is married to Floyd, who is farmer. They have six children: Leonard-28 years old; Nebrado Gill-26 years old; Merly-24 years old; Mariza-21 years old, all of them are high school graduates;f ollowed by Danilo-20 years old, a college student; and Mary jane-13 years old, a high school student. The couple hopes that their two youngest children will earn a college diploma.

loans.use: additional capital for business improvement.

loans.name: Ines

texts.en:
Ines E. is from the village of Talahiron, Kibawe Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Ines is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Ines owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to local community members. Ines has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Ines joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ines has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Ines is currently requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP; this money will be used to expand the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ines from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and further expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: expanding her business

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida T. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old and a widow with two school-aged children. To make a living, Aida owns and operates retail store where she buys and sells used clothing, known as ukay ukay, in the local community. Aida has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Aida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Aida is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita S. is from the village of Alibagu,Ilagan,Isabela. She is 55 years old, married, and has children.

Teresita owns and operates a business venture into buying and selling used bottles and steel in her junk shop. She earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her ninth loan taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Marie K. est marié, 59 ans et mère de 5 enfants. Elle tient une boutique où elle vend divers denrées alimentaires comme sucre, riz, huile. Elle compte améliorer  les conditions de vie de sa famille avec les revenus générés par son activité mais aussi faire face à la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Marie K., age 59, is married and the mother of five children. She runs a shop where she sells food staples, such as sugar, rice, and oil. She intends to use her profits to improve the standard of living of her family, and to pay for her children's school expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To retail food staples such as sugar, rice, and oil

loans.name: Lucia Celestina

texts.es: Doña Lucía Celestina Ordóñez C.  cuenta con 43 años de edad, es casada de oficios Artesana, “Elaboración de Ropa Típica” cuenta con un taller de 2 telares, habita junto a sus 4 hijos conjuntamente con su esposo, Ella y su esposo se dedican al mismo oficio cuentan con un empleado para la misma actividad, lleva 25 años de elaborar cortes Típicos en su residencia que se encuentra en el Paraje Chaquiral, Cantón Quiaquix, del departamento de Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente la demanda de su clientela a crecido, pero las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra no son suficientes para que ella pueda aumentar su capital, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención de comprar materia prima y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante a sus hijos, y que tengan mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Lucía Celestina Ordóñez C. is 43 years old and married. By profession, she is an artisan, specializing in the creation of traditional clothing. She has a workshop with two looms. She lives together with her husband and 4 children. She and her husband work in the same business, and they have an employee to help them with their work. For 25 years, they have made traditional clothing in their home, which is located in Paraje Chaquiral, in the canton of Quiaquix, Department of Totonicapán, Guatemala. Currently, customer demand has been rising, but the prevailing economic conditions are not favorable enough to allow her to increase her capital. For this reason, she came to the ASDIR Association to request a loan, with the aim of buying materials and supplies, which will allow her to increase her sales, while hoping also to be able to help her children advance and provide them with a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing materials and supplies to create traditional clothing

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is 29 years old and sells used caps and socks. He has been in the business for six years and his wife assists him. Previously, he was selling used clothes. He contributes his money in a merry-go-round (a local loan system) which helps him save his money.

Simon feels that since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to improve his business and support his family. He has requested KES 20,000 to add to his stock of caps.

Simon hopes to own a house and have a big business so as to support his family and invest. He sees himself having a stable business in the future. He describes himself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To add to his stock of caps

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine S. is from the village of  Lumbia in Cagayan de Oro City. She is 33 years old. Catherine is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Catherine owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Catherine has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Catherine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Catherine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Catherine is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Catherine's 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
40-year-old Gina B. is a new member of Kiva’s first field partner in the Philippines - ASHI. She is a domestic helper of someone in their village and it is her way to earn money.

The salary she is receiving from her employer monthly is just too small to support the growing needs of her family, especially her three children. Soon she will have to spend a lot because her eldest, 13-year-old, child will be in college. Her other two children are eight years old and one year old.

Gina really wants her children to graduate from college and have a different way of living. They must not be as poor as they are at present. Since her husband is unemployed, her aspiration would seem to be impossible. Therefore she wanted to have her own business using the loan she is presently requesting from Kiva.

Gina is planning to start a small business selling clothes. She plans for her items to be sold directly to people and she is optimistic that they would be salable because, compared to the ones sold in the market, the price of her goods would be much cheaper and her customers wouldn’t have to pay their fare to go to the market.

Gina really hopes that someday her business will grow to be more profitable and her life would be different.

loans.use: To purchase ready-to-wear clothes to sell

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat is the  wife of S. A..  They both are citizens of the mid-size city of Vehari, in Pakistan. They own a three room house in which they have been living with their four children: three sons and one daughter for the past 20 years. All of their children are getting an education from the  local school. Nusrat is a very caring lady. She stays at home and takes care of her family and does domestic chores. 
Her husband belongs to an agriculture profession. He supplies the pesticides and fertilizer to the farmers and earns profit from it. He has been in this profession for the past 15 years. His earnings are the main income for their family. Nusrat is requesting for a loan to buy pesticides and fertilizer in bulk to increase her husband's business profit.

loans.use: To buy pesticides & fertilizer to sell

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette O. is a 40-year-old, married woman from the town of Maamot, San Jose, Tarlac. Bernadette has 1 adult-age child. To earn a living, Bernadette owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. More specifically, she runs a general store, so her primary source of income is derived from selling a variety of products to her fellow community members. Bernadette has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2010, Bernadette joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. In turn, she hopes to be able to better engage in business activities and to thereby improve her standard of living. Bernadette is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan would be the first loan taken out by Bernadette from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to supplement her family's income.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches, which cover the Central and Northeastern areas of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional products and inventory

loans.name: Mawussé Amavi

texts.fr:
Cette femme a appris le métier de la couture, en 1994 elle a ouvert son propre atelier de couture qu’elle a appelé « LA GRACE DIVINE »,  plus tard elle a associé à ce commerce la vente des articles de mercerie, ainsi elle arrive à réaliser de grandes recettes.  Le commerce des articles de mercerie marche bien pour elle. Elle veut gonfler son stock de marchandises pour pouvoir satisfaire la demande de ses clients de plus en plus élevée raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter  des popelines, boutons,  satins, fils et autres
Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants.
texts.en:
After learning tailoring in 1994, this lady opened her own tailor store, that she called « LA GRACE DIVINE » (the divine grace), and later she included haberdashery in her business, so that she could make a good revenue. The haberdashery business is running quite well. She wants to improve her stock in order to respond to her customers' growing demand. For this reson she is requesting her first loan from WAGES, in order to purchase poplins, buttons, satin fabric, sewing thread and other goods. She is married and mother of two children.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of haberdashery supplies

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en: Douglas is a 28-year-old man. He runs a kinyozi (barber shop) and salon in Nairobi. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to buy two dryer machines, two blow driers and a manicure machine. Douglas serves the low-income earners from the Mukuru slums and describes his business as busy. A humble, honest and goal-oriented man, Douglas hopes to own a chain of beauty shops, buy a piece of land, build both commercial and residential houses, and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy two dryer machines, two blow driers and a manicure machine

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma C. is from the village of Acad, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 39 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Alma owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as some food for snacks, soft drinks, sugar, salt, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Alma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Alma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her sixth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Jelcome

texts.en:
48-year-old B. Jelcome has banked on finances from his audio music-sales shop to cater for his family of four for the last fifteen years in Kinyansano Village, Rukungiri. He has made profitable use of his idea that no one else was running this kind of business in his part of the country. In a month, he makes profits totalling 200,000 shillings.

This former teacher has no regrets over his decision to quit his profession. He reasons that he is now able to make more money than when he was a teacher, but he says he has had to summon up a lot of hard work and determination to be where he is. First he says he had to fight off detractors who were bent on seeing his business go up in smoke.

By virtue of the fact that he sells all genres of music, Jelcome has established for himself a big niche, as many people with different tastes of music patronize his place of work. With this loan, he is reckoning on buying more copies of original music discs and tapes to resell to his increasing clientele.

loans.use: To buy more copies of original music discs and tapes to sell

loans.name: Dulamjinhuu

texts.en:
Dulamjinhuu S. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her elder three children are university students.

Dulamjinhuu operates a dairy production trading business in her town with the help of her husband. She and her family started a dairy production trading business in 1992 and have had success in growing their business. She began her business with the working capital of 150,000 MNT and since it has operated successfully for many years, she has been able to increase it up to 2,000,000 MNT. She has many plans for the future and said, “My only wish is to be able to support my children to be better people in the future”. Dulamjinhuu is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase dairy products for her retail business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve his house he will put up a wall

loans.name: Jose Marcial

texts.es:
el señor Jose Marcial G. tiene 63 años de edad, tiene 5 hijos de los cuales uno esta en la escuela, Jose vive en coyolito desde hace 29 años y se dedica al negocio de venta de refrescos y servicios de moler maiz esta actividad la realiza desde hace unos años.
Jose utilizara el credito para la compra de repuestos de piezas para el molino y compra de refrescos al por mayor para vender al por mayor y al detalle.
su deseo es que sus hijos sean profesionales y que estudien cada dia mas para que puedan tener una mejor condicion de vida y puedan salir adelante por si solos.  
Jose es una persona muy gentil, responsable con mucho esmero y dedicacion por su negocio.
texts.en:
Mr. José Marcial García, 63, has five children one of whom is still in school. José has lived in Coyolito for the last 29 years and sells beverages. He also provides corn milling services. He has been in these lines of work for several years. José will use the funds to buy replacement parts for the mill and to buy beverages at wholesale for later resale at both wholesale and retail. His wish is that his children become professionals and that they study more every day so that they can have better living conditions and get ahead in life through their own efforts. José is a very kind, responsible person who puts much dedication and effort into his business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beverages and mill replacement parts.

loans.name: Warlita

texts.en:
Warlita R. is from the village of Clarin Plaridel Misamis Occidental. She is 63 years old. Warlita is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Warlita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, candies, powder soap, and juice drinks in the local community. Warlita has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Warlita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Warlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and invest in working capital. Warlita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Warlita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sabanoh United Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the members of the “Sabanoh United” group. They are women with small-scale businesses residing and trading in the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Hawa K. who is age fifty and was born in a place called Yoni. She is married with nine children. Her husband is a farmer and her children are all grown-ups.

For thirty years now, Hawa has sold market food – palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), groundnuts (peanuts), etc. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items in large quantity to add to her current stock. 

Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.

loans.use: To buy palm-oil, groundnuts, etc., in large quantity

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia  A. is a 49-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating her pig fattening and weaving businesses. She lives in Barangay Bog-ot, Argao, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $185. 

Cresencia is now borrowing 12,000 PHP so that she can purchase pig feed and vitamins.  This will be her 12th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Cresencia hopes to raise her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of pig feed and vitamins

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne A. is 27 years old and married to Stephen Wewa who is a carpenter. She supports four children with her business. They live in Kondele,  just few kilometers from Kisumu City and this is the location of her business   Carolyne buys fish from the fishmongers and prepares them well, fries and sells the food to her customers who are mostly the residence of Kondele.She has been in this business for one and half years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs. 12,000

Carolyne found out about KADET LTD through a friend who is also a member of KADET and she is now applying for her second loan of Kshs.35,000 after repaying her previous loans well. She intends to purchase more supplies of fish to sell to her customers.   With the profit generated from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to buy a motorbike which will ease with the transport of fish.

In the future she hopes to have a stable business and better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more stock of fish for sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Joyce Jendeka

texts.en:
Joyce Jendeka M. is 44 years old and married to Jeremiah Ombwori. They have three children who are in school and they live in Eldoret, Kenya. Joyce has been operating a stall in a market selling polythene bags for three years now, and she earns a monthly profit of KES 20000.

Joyce learned about KADET Ltd. through marketing awareness work being done in the area, and so she is applying for her first loan of KES 20000 from KADET Ltd., with which she intends to buy different sizes of polythene bags. The anticipated profits will be used to expand the polythene shop business.

Her deeper desire is to see her children realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy different sizes of polythene bags

loans.name: Diezan

texts.en:
Diezan P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 46 years old. Diezan is married and has 2 children. To earn a living, he owns and manages a rice farm. He works day to day to keep it productive. Diezan works hard to provide for his family. He wants his family to be happy and healthy.

Diezan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Diezan is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok S. (picture here), 25, and her husband, Mr. Bunthoeun Em, 22, live in a small village along National Road Number three about 20  kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2007 and have two young children. She also has her mother living with her.    
 
Sok operates a business renting space in her house to garment factory workers because her house is located near the garment factory. Her husband is a construction worker. She is asking for her first loan of $300 to purchase rice for food.

loans.use: To purchase rice for food.

loans.name: Agness

texts.en:
Agness Q. is a widow caring for three children. She sells fried and fresh fish in Takoradi.  She has been doing this for three years. Agness uses her income to educate, feed and clothe her children.  Agness will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to fry and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agness plans to reinvest in her business.

In this photo, Agness has on a tray a few fish on display. She also has iced blocks on the tray which she uses to keep the fresh fish cold for her customers.

loans.use: To purchase fresh fish to fry and sell

loans.name: Zaphaniah

texts.en:
Zaphaniah is sixty years old and married with thirteen children who are all adults. He is a farmer in Kisii town, western Kenya where he has been farming for over ten years. He sells his milk, bananas and maize to the local market.

He has requested this loan of 45,000KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and maintain a dairy cow. He says that his milk production will improve and his family will be assured of enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. His biggest challenge has been the poor weather conditions and diseases which affect his production. In future, he would like to start pig farming.

loans.use: To purchase and maintain a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase sewing supplies.

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 40 ans et 5 enfants, les huit membres du groupe Benkola habitent le quartier Pelengana sud, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché de Pelengana. Les membres du groupe font le commerce de céréales, d’habillements (chemises, T-shirt et bazins),  de jus locaux, de colliers et des fruits (banane et orange). 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire.
Madame Kotimi  Dembélé est connue à Pelengana Nord pour sa vente de fruits de toutes sortes. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 200 kg de banane et 3 sacs d’orange. Elle se ravitaille en fruits avec les forains de Koutiala en gros. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché de Pelengana à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Kotimi  Dembélé  espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.800FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les besoins du foyer. 
Elle ambitionne devenir grossiste dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
Benkola Group is composed of eight married women, who on average are 40 years old and have five children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Pelengana Sud, the administrative center of a rural municipality in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They came to know each other when they ran their businesses at the market in Pelengana. The group members sell cereals, clothes (shirts, T-shirts and basins), local fruit juice, necklaces and fruit (bananas and oranges).

Faced with the need to increase their working capital, the group members joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now at their first solidarity loan.

Mrs Kotimi Dembélé is known in Pelengana Nord for her diversified fruit stall. She intends to use her loan to buy 200 kilograms of bananas and 3 sacks of oranges. She gets her supplies from wholesalers at the market in Koutiala and retails her goods, for cash or credit, from her home, or hawking in the streets, or at the market in Pelengana to a clientele made up of women and men.

Mrs Kotimi Dembélé expects to make an average profit of 18,800 CFA francs a month, which will be reinvested in her business and spent to provide for her family. Her ambition is to become a wholesaler thanks to her partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To buy fruit

loans.name: Vith

texts.en:
Vith P., 29, resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. P. is a farmer and raises chickens, earning an income of $3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $5 per day. 

Each month, the family has to spend $45 on food and $85 on the other necessary expenses. 

P. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a new motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for family use

loans.name: Fenita

texts.en:
Fenita A. is married and has one child. She has completed her high school education.  Fenita sells tie-dye fabrics and local soap at Effiakuma Estate, near Takoradi, which she has been doing for 8 years. She is also a seamstress.  Her husband is a labourer.  Fenita uses her income to help her husband pay for household expenses.

Fenita will use the loan to purchase raw materials to be able to produce more soaps and clothes for sale. The new profits will be reinvested to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for the production of more soaps and clothes for sale.

loans.name: Mujeres Luchadoras 1 Group

texts.en:
Maricela´s story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Even her parents were Haitians. She was born in the Dominican Republic in a very rural community surrounded with sugarcane fields. Her group is located in San Pedro de Macoris, a city famous for baseball players and sugar cane industries. The main economic activities are a free trading zone, a cement factory, and others. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity. 

Maricela is the coordinator of her group, Mujeres Luchadoras 1 (Fighting Women). She makes her home in a simple structure with her long-term partner and six children. She says that her most difficult challenge is to build a house. Now she pays rent. She operates a miscellaneous product store (general store). 

Maricela is excited to take out her fourth loan through Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan to help grow her business. She has been in business for almost 16 years. Maricela plans to use this loan to buy clothes like pants and t-shirts, cosmetics, shoes, and especially women's apparel.
